div.p: THE Shepherdeſs of the Alps: A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS.
THE Shepherdeſs of the Alps: A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS. As it is performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for G. KEARSLY, No. 46, Fleet-ſtreet. M,DCC,LXXX.

argument.p: The Stanza in Page 69, marked with turn'd Commas is omitted in the Repreſentation.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: A view of the mountains of Savoy, in the road from Brançon to Medina. This view is a valley broke by little hills, between which ruſh irregular caſcades; theſe are again broke by the appearance of ſome cottages, which are diſtributed in perſpective to the very fartheſt diſtance: the diſtance conſiſts of mountains covered with ſnow; near the cottages are little groups of evergreens; under one of the hills is a ſmall vineyard, and, in the front, is a kind of outhouſe, where Blaiſe, Guillot, Renette, Jeannotte, and other villagers are diſcovered, with a preſs, baſkets of grapes, and other materials for making wine. Afterwards La Piere.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: PRESS the wine, preſs the wine,
Our annual harveſt is begun;
Red as a roſe
The liquor flows,
And ſhortly we ſhall drink the wine,
To chear our hearts when labour's done.
'Tis the right body, ſtrong and rough,
Let us the hogſheads fill;
Come, neighbour, come, you've work'd enough,
Now let me take a ſpill.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Guillot, nephew Guillot, thou ſtandeſt as idle, why do'ſt not take away the huſks of the old grapes, and bring a freſh baſket to put in the preſs? we ſhan't get done. Thou forgetteſt, I ſuppoſe, that to-morrow is to be our wine-harveſt?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No, I don't, uncle Blaiſe; nor that I am to be married to Jeannotte neither, and that's better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Well, well; buſineſs firſt, and pleaſure afterwards, Guillot. (La Pierre comes on) Servant, good people:—Pray can any of you tell me which is the way to the cottage of Maſter Blaiſe?

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: I am Maſter Blaiſe, my friend: what would'ſt thou pleaſe to have?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: A lucky rencounter, my friend! the Marquis De Bellemine and his Lady, who ſtopped here ſome months ago, in their way to Italy, are now hard by in their carriage, and have very earneſt buſineſs with you.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: O huſband! as ſure as you are alive they are come to take away Adelaide from us.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Oh, what that's your pretty Shepherdeſs of the Alps that we have heard ſo much talk about?—No, no friend, 'tis a different ſort of a ſtory, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Ay! what is it, pray?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: A ſhocking affair, friend, a ſhocking affair!—they have loſt their only ſon, and are now in ſearch after him; that's all.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Mercy, dear! that's ſad indeed.—Huſband, don't let them wait in the coach.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Wait in the coach! no, not for the world! Wife Renette, do you run home and bruſh up the things: Jeannotte, do you help her: Guillot, go and call Adelaide. Come, come, ſtir.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Here, Renette, I ſay, dear wife, prithee go,
And range, o'er the mantle, the things in a row;
Set abroach the beſt barrel, and take ſpecial care,
To poliſh the table, and ſet the arm chair;
And wife, above all, do you mind me—ſtay, ſtay;
Dear, me, now, what was I a going to ſay?
Oh, nothing;—now Guillot, why, child, thou ſtand'ſt ſtill!
Run quickly to Adelaide, ſhe's on yonder hill;
Tell her, that's a good lad, ſhe muſt inſtant come home,
For the gentlefolks, once more, to ſee us are come;
She'll know who you mean, grand madam, and ſir,
And there's none of us fit, to receive them, but her;
That's all; prithee, go now, don't ſtand like an elf,
And, Jeannotte, do you;—no, I'll do that myſelf;
We've enough to employ us,—pray, go if you pleaſe,
We muſt all be as buſy as ſo many bees.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Guillot, Jeannotte, Renette [who preſently goes off.]

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod, my uncle's in a woundy hurry, he has forgot his grapes and his wine now.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and no wonder; go child and call Adelaide; Jeannotte, do you come along with me,

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: I'll follow you directly; well, Guillot, why don't you go and do what you were bid?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Afraid, of what?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Of you.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Of me!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Yes, of you; don't I know very well you'd be as jealous as fury about it!

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Who's fault's that? en't you always ſmirking up to her, and ſaying ſoft things in her ear? do you think I don't take notice of your oglings, and leerings?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Me, ogle and leer! I wiſh I may die, whenever ſhe comes near me, if I don't run away from her as faſt as my legs can carry me; no, no, I thank you, I likes peace and quietneſs a little too much for that.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Why, then, if I do ſcold you, it's all becauſe I can't bear to ſee an upſtart creature come from nobody knows where—

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, for the matter of that, Jeannotte, every-body ſays ſhe muſt be a gentlewoman by diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Every-body ſays? Yes, every-body ſays a fine pack of nonſenſe about her education, and her manners, and her beauty. I ſhould be ſorry, indeed, if ſhe was the only beauty in the village, [bridling.]

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod, I don't know whether ſhe's handſome or ugly; you always takes care that I ſhan't look at her enough for that.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, you thinks 'tis very eaſy to blind me; I ſuppoſe you don't intend to look at her, neither when you go to call her home?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, if you are afraid of it, you had better go and call her yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Shall I Guillot? And do you forgive me, Guillot, for being ſo haſty?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I can't ſay I do quite, Jeannotte, and ſo what ſignifies lying? [ſullen.]

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: But I have no cauſe to be jealous, have I?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why lord, you know you have not as well as I do.

sp.speaker: Ican.
sp.p: Give me your hand, then, and we'll make it all up.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Nay, as to that, we'll kiſs and be friends if you will.

lg.l: When jealous out of ſeaſon,
When deaf and blind to reaſon,
Of truth we've no belief;
With rage we're overflowing,
Not why, or whether, knowing,
And the heart goes throb with grief.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But when the fit is over,
And kindneſs from the lover,
Does ev'ry doubt deſtroy;
Away fly thoughts alarming,
Each object appears charming,
And the heart goes throb with joy.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
Ay, 'tis all very well; but I know, in half an hour's time, 'twill be juſt as bad again; lord, lord, what a fine life I am likely to lead with her! to be ſure ſhe is the beſt girl in the world if ſhe was not ſo confounded jealous; I'cod I don't know what 'tis for; I am not ſo handſome, as I knows of, and then ſhe talks of loving me ſo plaguely! hang me, if one
might not as well be hated as ſcolded from morning 'till night. If I could but hit of a way to cure her of it! I was thinking, that ſuppoſe I made love to Adelaide out of a joke; but then, lord, ſhe'd never liſten to me; what put it in my head was, there's a mad comical ſort of a young gentleman has been plaguing me theſe two days to ſell him the ſtock that father left me, becauſe he wants to turn ſhepherd; and I have heard them ſay, that money is no bad thing to go a courting with; well, we ſhall ſee, but here comes the gentleman of the gentlefolks; I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: La. P.
sp.p: Here, ſtop young man, I want to ſpeak to you; you are going to call the ſhepherdeſs, en't you?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No, Sir, our Jeannotte's gone.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: I am damn'd ſorry for that, I wanted to ſee her; and, pray, has this blazing ſtar been long upon your meridian?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Star, Sir!

sp.speaker: La. P.
sp.p: Dam'me, there's no lowering one's ſelf to the comprehenſion of theſe brutes: to ſpeak in your language, then, has this young woman been long in theſe parts?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I believe it's about two years, Sir.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: And ſhe really is as divinely handſome as ſhe is reported to be?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, as to that, I can't ſay.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: I can't ſay! the clown! you muſt ſhew her to me; I am in love with her by reputation.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod, 'tis my belief ſhe has another gueſs ſort of a reputation than that, tho'

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: That! what, my friend? I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, then, to fall in love with ſuch folks as you and I.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: That's pleaſant, by Heaven; my friend, you are deceiv'd, I believe; there is ſome little diſtance between you and I.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: 'Tis my opinion there is, ſaving reſpect, for you have got a maſter, and I am maſter for myſelf: no offence, I hope.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: No, friend, your ignorance is your protection. What! I ſuppoſe you take me for one of the followers of the old people? if ſo, I muſt tell you that I have the honour to be, in ſome ſort, a companion of the Abbé de la Mouche, famous for his elegance and taſte; for his amours, for his poetry, and for his new conſtructed comb for the eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho! Lord, that muſt be a comical thing! ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho! the natural! The Abbé, I ſay, being on a viſit at their houſe, came with them this way, partly in ſearch after their ſon, who we underſtand has taken the road to France; and partly, like me, out of curioſity to ſee this wonderful creature, whoſe praiſes they have done nothing but din in our ears ever ſince they ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ah! likely enough.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p:
This, ſir, is the way I happened to be in company with the marquis and his lady, who are, by
all that's whimſical, the moſt fantaſtical, the moſt contrary, and the moſt ridiculous couple that ever yoked together in the ſhackles of matrimony; and, as if they were not abſurd enough of themſelves, they have brought with them that walking tombſtone, Count Triſte, who has cried a whole fortnight for the death of a wife, that any other man would have given half his eſtate to get rid of, and who like other tombſtones is continually telling the world of beauties and virtues that the deceaſed never poſſeſſed. But here comes the marquis and his lady.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And uncle along with them. I'cod, I'll get out of the way, or I ſhall have it for not going after Adelaide. [Going.]

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: But hear me, young man; I want you, I tell you, to introduce me to this fine creature.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Me, ſir?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Yes.—You'll tell her that I am, as you ſee, a genteel young fellow; and that—

lg.l: I gueſſes in part what it is you'd be at,
Make me what your maſter makes you:
But I'm none of your panders, I anſwer you flat,
So you ſee, my good friend, it won't do.
Ev'ry man to his trade.—Did I flatter and prate,
And make ſpeeches, and congé, and bow;
'Twould be juſt all as one, with that fine powder'd pate,
As to ſet you to work at the plow.
Beſides, and moreover, I told you before,
'Tis another gueſs ſort of a ſhe;
A ſenſible one, who would ſet little ſtore
By two ſuch poor ninnies as we.
You thought that a clown would not dare to ſay nay,
But you have not found me ſuch an elf;
So if to the young woman you've ought for to ſay,
You are likely to tell her yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Marque.
sp.p: Don't tell me, I'll never be comforted: he's dead; nay, I am ſure you know it, and conceal it from me.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Zounds, my dear! you won't hear reaſon: for my part, ſo far from thinking as you do, I look upon this little exploit as a ſmart, ſpirited thing. What the devil! a young fellow, with good clothes on his back, and money in his pocket, loſt, or dead!—A pack of nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Marque.
sp.p: Why ſhould he fly from us, then?—From me in particular—ſo indulgent a mother!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, boys, when they come to be towards twenty, think of ſomething elſe beſides indulgent mothers. Take my word for it he is after ſome wench.

sp.speaker: Marque.
sp.p: Oh! the very thoughts of it would make me die with confuſion.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Why, what the devil, would you always
tie him to your apron-ſtring? no, no, I hope my boy has too much of my blood in him for that.

sp.speaker: Marqueſ.
sp.p: Yonder comes the Abbé.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Damn the coxcomb, what did you bring him with you for? fire and water are not more oppoſite than him and me; I am a Roman of the time of the commonwealth, and he is an Italian of the preſent age, a fellow all pomatum and pulvilio; we ſhould have been here three hours ſooner if I could have got him away from his damned toilet.

sp.speaker: Marqueſ.
sp.p: Dear Marquis, don't talk ſuch ſtuff now.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nay, only let me draw his picture a little: after combing his eyebrows, and laying his rouge, he threw himſelf into an arm chair, took three ſorts of ſnuff out of the ſame ſnuff-box, ſneezed into a white ſilk handkerchief, wiped his mouth with a pink one, got up, looked in the glaſs, bridled, whirled about upon his heel, and then anſwered the ſalutation of good morrow, which I had given before all this ceremony began.

sp.speaker: Marqueſ.
sp.p: Heavens! how can you?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: This done, I had a ſecond impertinence to go through; he made me liſten to the contents of his whole pate folio, ſuch a cargo of ſonnets, epigrams, lampoons, and paſquinades, enough to furniſh out a ballad-ſinging Savoyard at a Dutch fair. However, you was determined to bring your Abbé, and I have brought my Count; we travel in a great ſtile, we have each of us a fool.

sp.speaker: Marqueſ.
sp.p: Your's is a fool, indeed, with his odious grief for his wife, who was neither amiable nor handſome, and who never loved him.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh, dam'me, I would have him; 'twas impoſſible to come all this way without ſome amuſement; what with your lamentations for your ſon, his ſuperficial cry, and the Abbé's ſupercilious laugh, you make a deviliſh good trio: but here comes the Abbé.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: My dear Marchioneſs, I have a million of pardons to intreat of you; but it was impoſſible to quit the carriage till I had adjuſted myſelf a little: my rouge was ſo rubbed about my face, that my cheeks were as ſallow as the Counteſs of Hypocondria's, and my forehead and noſe as red as the Marquis of Burgundy's, who lives upon ſwallowing pint bumpers; beſides, I was ſtruck on the way by the moſt beautiful idea for a paſtoral poem.

sp.speaker: Marqueſ.
sp.p: My dear Abbé, I am ſo unhappy about my ſon, I have no leiſure to reflect on any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Don't make yourſelf uneaſy, madam; the moment we get among the polite circles at Paris, I ſhall circulate a little poetical hue and cry through the hands of the moſt diſtinguiſhed characters, and your loſt ſheep will be inſtantly found, I dare ſwear; but you promiſed to introduce me to this ſhepherdeſs.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Introduce you! what the devil ſhould ſhe introduce you for? to frighten her! Why, what with your little black cloak, your feathers in your hat, and your wings at your ears, ſhe'll take you for ſome ſtrange bird of prey going to fly away with one of her lambs. Zounds! if Cato and Caeſar could give a look at Rome in its preſent ſtate—

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: They would find it filled, ſir, with men of elegance, politeneſs and taſte.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Foppery, luxury and effeminacy! Would any body believe this oſier twig was the produce of the ſame clime where grew ſo many ſturdy oaks? How manners change! Thoſe were the times when a veteran, pinned againſt a tree, would deſtroy you fourteen or ſixteen of his enemies with his own proper hand; but now, dam'me, if I ſhould not like to ſee what a figure you'd cut pinned againſt a tree.

lg.l: How unlike to theſe fops were our fathers of old!
Brave, manly, heroic, intrepid and bold;
Who had ſpirits like fire, and of health ſuch a ſtock,
That their pulſe ſtruck the ſeconds as true as a clock.
Without bridle or ſaddle, who'd mount on a nag,
And kill'd before ſun-riſe a boar or a ſtag;
Who, hunger provok'd by the keen, wholeſome air,
Would eat you for breakfaſt a pound of a bear.
But a fine mincing modern comes into the room,
A lump of pulvilio, a walking perfume;
In his tricks and his ſhape,
A direct human ape,
Who ogles and fluſhes,
And ſimpers and bluſhes,
And patches and paints,
And expires and faints,
And ſtammers and trips,
Takes ſnuff, bites his lips,
Liſps, coughs and lolls;
But to cut the thing ſhort,
Our men now at court,
Are nothing but ſo many ſixpenny dolls.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Savage and barbarous! the antients are only fit to be made ſubjects of my ſatires and odes; a delightful people to copy after to be ſure!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: They were the only people to copy after; they were manly and brave, friendly and generous; they were ſtrangers to luxury, their meals were frugal, and what nature required; and their dreſs was made for uſe, and not for ornament.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Their meals! Why, the beſt cook they ever had was not capable of making a ſauce robert; I ridiculed them for it in my little Impromptu, written at the bottom of Corregio's picture, where Ajax invites Agamemnon to dinner upon a boiled bull; and as to the reſt, they had neither ſpoons nor forks; nor table cloths, nor napkins; they eat with their fingers like their forefather Adam, and wiped them upon their beards like Methuſalem.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Very well, Mr. Fop.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: No, no, Marquis, our buildings, our ornaments, our dreſs, our eating, are ſo many refinements that do honour to the preſent age, and horridly expoſe the ignorance of our anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: All this may be true in the language of foppery; but, in the language of common ſenſe, in your buildings and ornaments you have exchanged ſolid for ſuperficial; your dreſs has metamorphoſed the human ſpecies into apes and monkeys; and as to your repaſts, you have inverted the ſeaſons to procure eatables without their natural flavour; and all your improvements have only taught you to have peas and ſtrawberries at Chriſtmas, and melons and pine-apples, in deſpight of nature.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Go on, Sir, 'twill only ſerve as minutes for my next paſquinade.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: As for you, you are out of meaſure ridiculous; you thought you could not ſufficiently diſgrace your family, which is truly antient and noble, by imitating the other faſhionable follies and extravagancies, but you muſt get into the church, be made an Abbé, one of that mongrel kind of animals who now indeed ſwarm all over the world, half clergyman, half coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Well, Marquis, we had better not diſpute, for, I fancy, we ſhall never agree. At preſent, I believe, the Marchioneſs wiſhes to repoſe herſelf; therefore, good man, if you'll ſhew us your place we ſhall be obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: To be ſure, Sir, if your honour pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: And then, my dear Madam, you ſhall introduce me to the Shepherdeſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thoſe are your nobles of the preſent times; if my ſon had nothing more noble about him, he ſhould not catch me ſcampering, the devil knows where, over the Alps after him in compliment to any wife in the world; bur here comes a coxcomb of another kind; a fellow who cries for his wife with one eye, and leers at every girl he meets with the other; I ſhall divert myſelf with him, or I am miſtaken. What, ſtill unhappy, Count? Zounds, man! I thought this journey would have diverted you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, I told you, Marquis, what a wretched companion I ſhould make for you.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Come, come, you muſt ſhake off your chagrin; conſider you are going to ſee the lovely Shepherdeſs of the Alps, and would you viſit your miſtreſs with a face a yard long?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Miſtreſs! lord, Marquis, how you rattle! me think of a miſtreſs, indeed, who have ſo lately loſt ſuch a treaſure, my poor dear! Ah, thou beſt of wives, when ſhall I ever ſee thy fellow!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I tell you this Shepherdeſs is her very picture, has every trace of her, from the caſt of her eye, to the mole upon her left cheek, that people uſed to take for a black patch.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Captivating ornament!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: She has, I aſſure you; in ſhort, I am determin'd you ſhall ſee her; your ſorrow preys too much upon you, and the only way to forget one woman is to make love to another.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why this grief is very terrible without doubt; and, if there was any way to cure it—but then how could I expect any woman would liſten to me, broke down as I am by affliction?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Not liſten to you! damn it, don't talk to me in that ſtile, don't I remember when you and I went to Venice.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, upon the road, the lovely Brunetta who played upon the mandilina?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Ah, rogue!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I ſhall never forget her; what eyes!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What teeth!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Pearl.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What cheeks!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Roſes.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: With the dew upon them when ſhe cried at parting from you, eh, Count!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh, never was man ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Where was the Counteſs then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Alas! poor ſoul, ſhe little thought I was wronging her; but my ſins are puniſhed, for ſhe is taken away from me, and I ſhall never be happy any more.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Yes, you will. Come, come, prepare yourſelf to ſee this wonder, ſhe'll wound you deeper than the Brunetta did.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, I won't think of it; melancholy ſhall be my only miſtreſs; nor ſhall I expect relief but in the cold tomb! Are you going to ſee her now?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Preſently.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, adieu.—I'll find out ſome corner where I may indulge my miſery. (Going)—And ſo ſhe reſembles my poor deceaſed dear! (returns)—I ſhould like juſt to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: You ſhall not only ſee her, but have her in your arms.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, and preſs her to my boſom!—No, no; don't talk ſo.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: You ſhall, I tell you.—The charming, tempting, heavenly—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yielding creature!—hey, Marquis!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Ay, this is ſomething like: zounds
〈◊〉 think of blubbering and crying! and yet, to ſay the truth, I don't wonder at it, for women make us juſt what they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He's very right, they do make us juſt what they pleaſe, indeed.

lg.l: There's ſomething in women their lovers engage,
Of whatever complexion, or ſtature, or age;
And ſhe who would frighten a mere ſtander-by,
Is a Venus herſelf in the fond lover's eye.
If ſhe's pale, never ſwan was a tenth part ſo fair;
If tawny, like jet are her eyes and her hair;
If Xantippe herſelf, her ſcolding's thought wit;
If meek, all good wives to their huſbands ſubmit.
If a pigmy, how neat are her air and her mien!
If a ſteeple, ſhe's graceful, and walks like a queen!
If a girl in her teens, all's handſome that's young;
If eighty, her fortune ſays—World hold your tongue.
In ſhort, to dear women 'tis given to pleaſe,
And tho' the whim often ſhould take them to teaze,
To perplex, to torment, and a thouſand things more;
They're the deities men were all born to adore.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, 'tis a very fooliſh thing, and I would not have you think any more of it.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: That's my affair, Guillot.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Unleſs I ſell you my cottage, and ſheep, in ſhort, all my ſtock, you ſhall be unhappy!—I don't underſtand it for my part.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: And yet, Guillot, 'tis very true.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: What a whim, ſir, under favour!—A gentleman, as you ſeem to be, rich, and well-born, to come here and keep ſheep!

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: What would you have me ſay to you?—'Tis for my pleaſure—I come to taſte at a diſtance from the town that happineſs which heaven has in ſtore for you. The candour that reigns in your eyes, convinces me your happy days are the charming image of the golden age. To know love is to know happineſs; 'tis in the woods he is born: the humbleſt eſtate is, for me, the ſweeteſt; and your's ſeems the retreat of innocence and tranquillity.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: For me, who am a ſhepherd, I ſwear to you, that our lives have ſome good moments, but it's hard, it's hard.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I know all this, Guillot; and yet I perſiſt.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Well, I can't help it, Sir; I muſt not conſent to it. What would our neighbours ſay?—To be ſure, if I had a mind, nobody could furniſh you with better things for your purpoſe, than I—let me ſee—I have a—but, no, no, no; I can't think of it.—Servant, Sir, (going)

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Nay, Guillot, pray come back. I'll give you a handſome price for your things.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: No, no, ſir; 'tis not that. I dare ſay you have money enough, and no doubt but you would part with it in a gentleman-like way; and, as I ſaid before, if things were agreeable, I don't know any body could match you better than I; but, Lord! only conſider; 'tis wrong, ſir, 'tis indeed: how many ſheep did you pleaſe to want?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I'll buy all you have.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: All I have! oh, no; I could not ſpare you all I have; beſides, what ſhould you buy any for?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Well but, Guillot—
sp.stage: [As they are diſputing, the ſymphony begins.]

lg.l: I've twenty ſheep now in the fold,
Twelve ewes, eight weathers, one year old.
For thoſe ſame ſheep a hundred crowns.
Oh zounds!
Nay, nay.
I won't I ſay.
Sho, ſho.
No, no.
Sir, 'tis too much; you're wrong, you're wrong.
I tell you, Guillot, hold your tongue.
Well, if it muſt be ſo, it muſt;
You'll ſay 'twas forc'd on me, I truſt.
My friend, you really are too nice;
A hundred crowns! 'tis juſt the price:
Come, come, go on.
I'd rather not.
Nay, prithee, be not ſuch a ſot.
My cottage neat as e'er you ſaw,
Thatch'd but laſt autumn with new ſtraw—
Well, well, for that two hundred crowns.
Oh zounds! &c.
Why, you'll take all!
'Tis my deſign;
And for your clothes I'll give you mine.
The village all would ſay 'twas pride.
Come, Guillot, what have you beſide?
Why, I've a faithful dog as true,
But he'll be of no uſe to you.
Well, for the dog I'll give ten crowns.
Oh zounds! &c.

div.stage: SCENE, Almoſt the ſame View differently diſtributed; on one Side is a Hill; at the Bottom of the Hill an old Oak; and, at the Foot of the Oak, a kind of ruſtic Tomb.

sp.p:
Here my afflicted mind nouriſhes its pain; I cry, and I am comforted; 'twas here I ſaw my huſband; here, alas! I kept him from the battle; here he bid me adieu; here I waited his return; here, being diſhonoured,
loſt without reſource, he ſeized the moment, while I had fallen ſenſeleſs at the news, to take away that life which I had rendered odious; and, Oh! cruel and tender remembrance, 'twas here I built his tomb! but what flock moves this way? I never before ſaw the ſhepherd who conducts them; I'll turn aſide to avoid his preſence.

lg.l: By love and fortune guided,
I quit the buſy town;
With cot and ſheep provided,
And veſtments of a clown.
Thus have I barter'd riches
For a ſhepherd's little ſtock;
A crook, to leap o'er ditches,
And well to climb each rock;
A faithful dog, my ſteps to guide,
A ſcrip and hautboy by my ſide;
And my horn, to give the alarm
When wolves would harm
My flock.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Ah, ſay then who can blame me?
For beauty 'tis I roam;
But, if the chace ſhould tame me,
Perhaps I may come home.
'Till then I'll give up riches, &c.

sp.p: At laſt I am a ſhepherd; how many contending ſenſations do I feel! ah! finiſh, love, let me behold her, the report alone of whoſe charms induced me to leave my country and my family. Beautiful and touching Adelaide! perhaps thou wilt liſten to a timid ſhepherd, when thou wouldſt ſtartle at the voice of love! alas, the god thou flieſt is my guide; but let me rather ſeek occaſion to do her kindneſs than ſurprize her too abruptly; yonder ſhe is; I cannot be miſtaken, I'll watch upon her ſteps for ever but I'll find out ſome way to oblige her.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: He is gone, and I am irreſiſtibly drawn again towards this ſpot.

sp.speaker: Y. Bel.
sp.p: Gods, what an angel!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Hark! here's ſome one coming.

sp.speaker: Y. Bel.
sp.p: Shall I ſpeak to her? [coming forward] Here comes that fool Guillot, I muſt ſtep aſide or he'll diſcover me. Gods, what an angel!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Heaven defend me! what do I ſee, who is that, Guillot?

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis Guillot out of his ſenſes; Guillot grown rich; in ſhort, Guillot who ſo loved me yeſterday, today hates me worſe than poiſon.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this! how came you ſo fine, Guillot?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Another gentleman and I changed clothes, that's all.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: But why does your finery make you deſpiſe Jeannotte?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: For a very good reaſon; I intends to make love.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas! Guillot, broken vows and inconſtancy will never recommend you to me.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh lord, I ſhan't be falſe-hearted to you a bit, I always had a ſort of a ſneaking for you; only I thought when I was but a poor ſhepherd, you'd turn up your noſe at me; I hardly believe you will now though.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Did any body ever hear ſuch a wretch? I'll tear your eyes out! and I'll tear her eyes out! and I won't ſuffer it, ſo I won't.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: How will you do to help yourſelf? you ſee, Mrs. Jeannotte, what your jealouſy has brought you to, and ſo no more words; if Adelaide will have me, I'll have her.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: This love, then, which is ſaid to be ſo ſweet, makes, every-where, unhappineſs. If it is dangerous for ſhepherds, for whom is it harmleſs?

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Alas! they ſay, how ſweet is love!
And talk of joys that lovers prove;
'Tis folly, madneſs all and rage,
Its joy's an hour, its pain an age.
Come, come, be friends, I ſee the truth,
This is ſome quarrel.
No, forſooth,
'Tis honeſt earneſt.
What, again!
Thou art the baſeſt of all men;
I cannot bear it, ſo I can't.
Come, come, dry up her tears.
I ſhan't,
I've ſaid my mind, and I ſay ſtill,
If I can get your kind good will,
I'll marry you to-night.
Oh, dear!
Such unkind uſage who can bear!
Alas! &c.
Plainly, friend, Guillot, hear me ſpeak;
Thoſe who their vows of love can break,
Each promiſe falſe, each oath a lie,
As from an adder would I fly.
I ſay, you take not the thing right!
She's croſs, and ſcolds from morn till night;
That all the neighbours cry out ſhame.
If that's the caſe, then, ſhe's to blame;
Sweetneſs and gentleneſs ſhould move,
Alone, to a return of love;
But if 'tis owing to her fears,
Leſt ſhe ſhould loſe you, dry her tears.
Not I, indeed.
There now ſee there!
I've neither for her love nor care;
And if you'll have me not, d'ye ſee,
Another may—all's one to me.
I'll bear't no longer, perjur'd wretch!
There, there, you ſee it was no fetch.
Alas! &c.

sp.stage: [They go off at the End of the Trio different Ways.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: The ſame View that was ſeen at the beginning of the firſt Act.

sp.p: I'VE watched till I have loſt myſelf; but how to accoſt her—how to manage the timidity of this ſolitary beauty—if ſhe is unhappy, her heart will have need of conſolation. After all, we ſeem as if we were alone in the univerſe, and ſhall be every thing to each other. If we converſe, we ſhall not be far from friendſhip, and friendſhip, at our age, oft changes into love; but ſhe is here. If I am right in my obſervation, ſhe has already ſome curioſity concerning me; I'll draw aſide and endeavour to heighten it, by mingling with her ſong the ſound of my hautboy.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: The nightingale gives me his wonted evening ſalutation; and, as I return with my flock, anſwers my ſighs with a ſweet complaining ſong.

lg.l: Sweet melancholy bird again—

sp.p:
Heavens! what do I hear! a hautboy accompanies me; 'tis the ſhepherd who leads his ſheep to feed at the foot
of the mountain. [Hautboy again.] A ſhepherd!—let us liſten— [again] 'tis an enchantment; is it poſſible to believe that ſentiment, alone, can be ſo faithful a guide! who will dare after this to ſay, that taſte is the fruit of a ſlow culture? It ſeems as if fortune pitied me, and ſent this ſhepherd as a new echo to anſwer to my griefs.

lg.l: Sweet melancholy bird, again,
As thou art wont at every eve
My hopeleſs ſorrow in ſoft ſtrain,
Ah echo to me, and relieve.
Alas! to anſwer my ſad woe,
Inſympathy all nature grieves;
The rivers ſeem with tears to flow,
The zephyr ſighs amidſt the leaves.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: A ſhepherd this! but hold; the Marquis of Bellemine is in ſearch after his only ſon; it muſt be ſo; but here he comes; his air, his manner, his addreſs all confirm me in my ſuſpicions; I'll ſpeak to him; oh how I ſhall bleſs this accident if I can conſole this unfortunate pair!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Do you lead your ſheep far from hence, ſhepherd?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I don't lead them at all, they go themſelves to the paſtures which they love.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: You are not of theſe parts then?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Nor, as it ſhould ſeem, born to be a ſhepherd.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Since I am one, doubtleſs I was born to be ſo; I know not where I am. [Aſide]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: He ſeems troubled, and, as if fearful of being betrayed; 'tis ſurely as I gueſſed: no, no, your air, your language, all convince me that heaven deſigned you a more favourable lot.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Why ſhould you think ſo? 'twould be as reaſonable for me to believe the ſame thing of you; you have the air of an inhabitant of the woods, and yet in that eſtate I ſee you; but nature is the mother of ſhepherds as well as kings; and ſometimes with a light and favouring hand beſtows talents and graces on the ſimple and timid ſhepherd as the object of her choice. The flowers which are born in the country want no culture; nor have the birds that ſing ſo ſweetly any leſſons but thoſe of nature.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: I am convinc'd—you would deceive me I tell you. The art with which you animated the hautboy, in a ſimple inhabitant of the woods would, indeed, be a rare prodigy.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: 'Tis your voice tis the prodigy in a ſimple ſhepherdeſs. [Inſinuating.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: What has inſtructed you?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: My heart and my ear. You ſing, I am raviſhed, and my tractable hautboy longs to anſwer you; is this art difficult? Alas! to explain what one feels, coſts nothing: when one has ſenſibility and tenderneſs to form enchanting ſounds, one has only to hear you; 'twas that ſtruck me with admiration, and my mouth and my hautboy were inſpired by my mind.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: But you expreſſed ſadneſs!

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Becauſe you inſpired it: take a laughing air, and I'll play an allegro.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: No; theſe places were not made for vain and frivolous joy; complaints and ſighs only are found here.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Let me then ſigh with you. [Tenderly.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas! I penetrate his deſigns, and muſt prevent them. Are you then unhappy?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: What if I am?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Perhaps then heaven has ſent you that we may conſole each other; but there muſt be a mutual confidence. At ſun-riſe to-morrow, let me find you at the foot of that oak where firſt you heard me ſigh; there my heart will I lay open to your eyes; but you muſt leave me now.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I obey. To-morrow at ſun-riſe: my impapatience overcomes me! Oh, how I ſhall count each moment!

lg.l: O Time, no more ſhall it be ſaid,
Thy pond'rous wings are tip'd with lead,
If pitying a lover's ſorrow,
Thou'lt haſte and quickly bring to-morrow.
Love overpowers me,
Impatience devours me,
I dread, yet long to ſee this ſpot;
Alike in turn,
I freeze and burn,
And fear and wiſh—I know not what.

sp.p: Thus I ſhall be ſure of rendering him to his friends: no, no, I no longer entertain a doubt that under this ſhepherd's habit I have ſeen the young Marquis of Bellemine; Guillot's appearance, every thing confirms it: but whence does it ariſe? no matter whence; every thing adds to my unhappineſs; his deſign is but too evident, and he'll join his intreaties with theirs to reconcile me to the world—ineffectual endeavours!

lg.l: The little bark may ſafely ride
Where neither rocks nor quickſands lie,
But driven to ſea by wind and tide,
As ſwift as ſwallows ſkim the ſky.
The horror of the foaming main,
The lightning's glare, the thunder's roar,
Give little proſpect that again,
Poor bark! ſhall ever reach the ſhore.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Well, Abbé, I accept your propoſal; I'll ſign articles of peace immediately, if you'll enter into a treaty to ſhew off the Count.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: And you promiſe, for the future, not to find fault either with my dreſs or manners.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: You may uſe nineteen perfumes to as many pocket handkerchiefs, and take out forty toothpicks at one dinner time, without my ſaying a word: nay, I'll even praiſe your poetry; and I am ſure that's ſacrifice enough in all conſcience.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: To buſineſs then: the Count has been teazing me to introduce him to the ſhepherdeſs.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Him, a brute! He'd be as ridiculous as the bear in my fable, that makes love to the panther.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Liſten to me: you muſt know I have been out upon the ſearch, (for I like, I confeſs, to look at a freſh country girl) and I have found one, the very thing, to paſs upon the Count.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: An admirable thought, curſe poiſon me! the very epiſode to my little Serenata I made the fellows act ſo often after Goldoni's Comedies.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: And to make it impoſſible that he ſhould know the true from the counterfeit, I have got the good man, Blaiſe, to accommodate him and you at the cottage of one of his neighbours; ſo there's no fear of his encountering Adelaide.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: But, Marquis, are not you afraid the girl herſelf will diſcover who ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Not at all; I underſtand ſhe has been ill uſed by ſome fellow, who was to have married her; and I have adviſed her to ſnap up the Count out of revenge, and inſtructed her how to behave at the firſt interview.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Excellentiſſimo! damnato di mio! poetical juſtice in every conception!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: But here he comes: remember our firſt attack is to ſee how extravagant we can make him by extolling the Counteſs to the ſkies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dear Marquis, what has become of you? 'tis cruel to leave me to myſelf in ſuch diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: But, my dear friend, you muſt take comfort.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, Marquis, there's no comfort for me.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I grant you the Counteſs was a moſt divine creature.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Don't mention her.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What grace! what ſpirit! what gaiety!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Had not ſhe! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I ſhall never forget how moſt inceſſantly ſhe laughed at my lampoon upon the Friar that we perſuaded to go to the play in a domino.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Did ſhe? oh! oh! oh! what an irreparable loſs!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Particularly the deſcription of the old fellow when his falſe frizure fell off, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! to ſee his bald pate!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I remember ſomething of it, peeping up above his blue ſilk domino with gold frogs.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: True, true, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He muſt cut a ridiculous figure, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Abbé
sp.p: Damn'd ridiculous

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: [finiſhing the laugh] ha! ha! ha!—a—a ah! I don't wonder that my poor dear ſhould laugh at it, oh! [ſighs] what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I wiſh we could conſole you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, I'll never be conſoled; every thing calls her to my mind, every body admired her.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: What admirable talents!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: How charmingly ſhe played upon the harpſichord!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhingly! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Eſpecially the cantata I wrote her: her judgment and finger were petrifying, ſtrike me ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: How ſhe ſung!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! delightful! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: One ſong in particular.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, what was that? I remember all.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Let me ſee, 'twas in one of the operas.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Caro amore?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: The very thing.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah, ſhe did ſing it delightfully indeed!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Do you remember her manner, Abbé?

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I'll try

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh! that was not at all like it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Not a bit, not a bit; ſhe glided over the paſſages, ah! [ſighing]

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Thus

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, I'm out of patience with you, this was it

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Exquiſitiſſimo!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Stop, I have not done. [finiſhes with a cantabile.]

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Enchanting! no, dam'me, there's nothing in the world could make a man amends for the loſs of a woman who could ſing in that manner.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, my friends, there is nothing in this world worth my notice.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: 'Tis very true; merit like this was irreſiſtible. I am ready to cry myſelf, when I think of your ſituation.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis friendly of you, my dear Marquis.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: 'Tis terrible to loſe ſo many united accompliſhments, for we have not half mentioned them.—She ſung divinely to be ſure, but ſhe danced—

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I remember it! may roſe-water poiſon me, but ſhe was grace itſelf: her minuet was the moſt delightful thing. I remember I wrote her a litttle complimentary trifle on it, called, "Venus in the Fourth Poſition."

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O charming!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Very true; and then to ſee her ſwim an allemande! I remember ſhe had one particular trip that was beautifully elegant—let me ſee—how was it?—Give me your hand, Abbé.
sp.stage: (He ſings an allemande, and they dance ridiculouſly)

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, don't diſtract me ſo, pray.—Oh dear! you are not right at all; you bouree what you ſhould chaſſé.

sp.speaker: Marq.
Count.
sp.p: Zounds! 'tis no more like her—Give me your hand, Abbé. (Count ſings, and dances about 'till he falls quite out of breath upon a bank)—Oh! oh! oh! what can ever make me amends for the loſs of her?

sp.speaker: Marquis
sp.p: Yonder's my counterfeit ſhepherdeſs! do you begone.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Well, Count, I ſhall find you; I muſt ſpeak to my fellow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Adieu, Abbé.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Adieu!—take care you don't make out the little ballad I wrote upon the road.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, about inconſtancy?—no, there's no danger of that.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Take care, that's all.—It runs thus, you know.

lg.l: The riſing ſun Lyſander found,
Shedding tears o'er Phillis's tomb;
Who ſwore he ne'er would leave the ground,
But paſs his life in that dear gloom.
Tearing his hair, the frantic youth,
Cried, "food and raiment I deny;
And with my life ſhall end my truth,
For love of Phillis will I die."
The radiant god made half his tour,
The kine ſought ſhelter from his heat,
Which paſs'd within the cottage door,
Where poor Lyſander—drank and eat.
His dinner finiſh'd, up he roſe,
Stalk'd, ſighing, ſilently and ſlow,
To where were hung his Sundays clothes,
Then took a walk to chace his woe.
The ſun to Thetis made his way,
When underneath a friendly ſhade,
A ſhepherd ſung, in accents gay,
His paſſion for a gentle maid.
O lovers, what are all your cares!
Your ſighs! your ſufferings! tell me what?
To Daphne 'tis Lyſander ſwears,
And lovely Phillis is forgot.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I am glad he's gone, the troubleſome fool.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tireſome to a degree; well, my dear Marquis, have you ſeen the Shepherdeſs?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Yes, and what's better, I have prepared her to ſee you, and what's better ſtill, here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Does ſhe? you throw me all over in an agitation.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Well, I'll leave you together; remember ſhe's all delicacy.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Now have mercy upon her; don't wound her too deep.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ah you bantering devil. There will be a fine ſcene between us, I ſuppoſe; I ſhall perſwade, ſhe'll heſitate, and then, ah I know how it will be.

lg.l: Firſt, Sir; may I periſh dear creature,
Fall down and expire at your feet,
If in air, ſtature, mien, ſhape, and feature,
Any Venus was e'er ſo compleat.
Then, madam; lord, you're ſuch another,
I ne'er ſaw the like in my days;
You make ſuch a rout, and a pother,
And then you've ſuch wheedling ways.
Permit me—I vow, Sir,
To raviſh—nay, now, Sir;
A heavenly kiſs—pray be civil;
Oh nectar—you touze me;
Ambroſia—and blouze me—
Get along, you agreeable devil.
Fir'd all over,
Now, the lover
Sighs nor tears can ſtay;
Bold he ventures,
Pleaſure enters,
Reaſon flies away.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: She is a moſt heavenly creature.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Was any poor wretch ever ſo uſed as I am?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: She ſeems very unhappy, indeed; I am too much overwhelmed with diſtreſs myſelf not to pity her.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: I could cry for vexation.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Poor ſoul!—I'll try to comfort her.—Dear, lovely young creature, may I preſume to aſk if you are the pretty Shepherdeſs of the Alps?

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; there's a great many people have ſaid that of me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And they ſay you have ſomething upon your mind that very much troubles you.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; I have, indeed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And may I take the liberty, divine creature, to aſk what it is?

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I would not tell every body, but ſuch a gentleman as you are, I think there can be no great harm.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Ingenuous and ſenſible?—'tis too great a ſacrifice to let her ſtay here.—Well, my love.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Well, ſir; my ſtory's very ſhort; 'tis only, ſir, that a young man was to have married me, but he grew rich, and deſpiſed me, and ſo has left me to the wide world.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twould be a great ſtroke to carry her off!—My dear, your ingenuity demands as ingenuous a return: our caſes, then, are exactly alike; death has taken away my wife, and ambition your huſband.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: No, ſir; 'twas another ſhepherdeſs that took him away.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Simplicity itſelf! I like that.—So you ſee, my angel, we are both miſerable alike.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I pities you; it muſt be a ſad thing for you, indeed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh! a very ſad thing; I ſhall never be happy any more.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Dear ſir, don't ſqueeze my hand quite ſo hard.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I was only admiring how like your hand and arm is to my poor deceaſed wife's.—And ſo, my love, he has quite forſaken you? (offering to kiſs her)

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Lord, ſir!—yes, ſir, he has indeed, and I am ſure I don't know what I ſhall do.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I muſt have her.—And have you liſtened to no offers ſince this affair?

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: There have been none made to me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your frankneſs encourages mine, and if I did not fear to offend your delicacy, (for they tell me you have a prodigious deal of that) I would tell you that I have a vacancy in my heart and my houſe, and that if my perſon was agreeable—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: You, ſir!—Lord, ſir! how can I expect ſuch a great man as you? Beſides, if you can forget your wife ſo ſoon, what would ſhortly become of me?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh my dear! there is not the leaſt compariſon: ſhe was old enough to be your mother.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Oh! that indeed is another thing.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And then you ſeem to have a heavenly temper.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, I'm a monſtrous good-humour'd girl.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Whereas ſhe was the very devil, and it was impoſſible to have any peace with her, from morning 'till night.—Come then to my arms, there thou ſhalt
find an aſylum, and the end of all thy woes; coach, title, equipage, every happineſs ſhall attend you; diamonds—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: A coach! oh dear!—but, ſir, you muſt give me time to think of it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, but—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I won't conſent to any thing, unleſs you leave me now; and I'll tell the other gentleman when you ſhall ſee me again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: One kiſs then for earneſt. [Kiſſes her.] Rapture paſt expreſſing!

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: A coach and jewels! but here comes Guillot: I ſhall match the gentleman now, I believe.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: So, Mrs. Jeannotte, you are there.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I am; and what then?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Nay, nothing at all; your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: One word, Mr. Guillot, if you pleaſe: pray when is the wedding day to be? I ſuppoſe, Madam Adelaide has conſented; I beg you'll let me be bridemaid.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: To be ſure, Jeannote, one can't do leſs than that for old acquaintance ſake. I ſee ſhe's as mad as fury, but I'll ſeem not to mind it. Why now, that is as it ſhould be; I knew all along you did not love me, and ſo you know how fooliſh it would have been for two people to be hampered together in a yoke, for nothing in the world but to draw contrary ways.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p:
Very true, Mr. Guillot; and I dares to ſay you'll be more happy with a runaway vagabond creature than with an honeſt vartuous girl, that's not
aſhamed to tell who her parents are; you may take that wipe as you think proper, ſir. A great credit to you, to be ſure, inſtead of working as an honeſt man ought, to be dancing about in a fool's frock, and running after beauties.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, if I was you, Jeannotte, if I did not care for't, I would not trouble my head about it.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Oh, not I indeed: I was only going to ſay, ſir, that tho' you fancy me jealous and ugly, and all that's bad, there are men in the world think me the pretty ſhepherdeſs of the Alps.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I don't gain-ſay it.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Beſides and moreover, to let ſome folks know other folks can get rich as eaſy as them; nay, and can keep their coach: what do you think of that? and have their jewels, and their ſervants to wait upon them.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod! well done Jeannotte, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: I can tell you, ſir, 'tis not a thing to laugh at.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, how canſt thou be ſuch a natural? do you think this ſham will paſs upon me? don't I know 'tis all flim-flam to try me. Well, Jeannotte, I cannot help ſaying but I am ſorry for thee.

sp.speaker: Jean.

lg.l: Time was, when Guillot by my ſide,
Dreſs'd out in all our Sunday's pride,
And dancing by yon beechen tree,
'Twas love and joy, and who but we!
But worſe luck's our's, we're both grown great,
And folly ſo bewitches,
Content is chang'd for pomp and ſtate,
And happineſs for riches.
Time was, when Guillot told the prieſt,
We'd marry at our harveſt feaſt:
Alas! what will the good man ſay,
Without his fee when ſent away?
For Worſe luck's our's, &c.

sp.p: A coach and jewels! what is all this? I ſurely have not been playing the fool 'till I have loſt her. I'cod, this puts me in mind, when I was a boy, of catching birds, and letting them go again.

lg.l: Many and often was the time,
When up a tree I us'd to climb,
To ſearch for birds neſts in it;
And as the boughs I've mov'd about,
Perhaps the noiſe has frightened out
All but the laſt fledg'd linnet.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The little thing, from bough to bough,
I'd watch with anxious care, and now
Dodge hither, and now thither,
Till in the cage I've thought it ſure;
Forgetting to ſecure the door,
It flew, the Lord knows whither.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: What could I do? no uſe to cry,
Whimper, put finger in the eye,
Blubber, and make a pother;
I e'en was forced to be content,
And onwards as I whiſtling went,
Perhaps I've found another.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Well, whenever we die, ſhe ſhall find herſelf in as good a caſe as we are.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: We'll give her all our ſheep, and our cottage.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Ay, and every bit of dowlas that I have been ſo long a ſpinning; for I love her as much as if ſhe was my own child.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: And ſo do I, ſhe's ſo good, ſo ſweet, ſo genteel, for all the world like thee, when thou wert of her age.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Lord, thou art joking good man.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: I en't indeed; every-body ſaid you looked the ſweeteſt, and dancing the nimbleſt in all the village.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: 'Tis thy kindneſs makes thee think ſo.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Not at all, I have not forgot when I firſt ſaw you dancing under the elm; but above all upon our wedding-day; lord how I did love thee!

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Ay, and thou loveſt me now too.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Ah, but in fifty years of marriage the firſt fire gets a little low; however, with pleaſure I recal the image.

lg.l: Well I remember me, 'twas on the firſt of May,
With garlands and noſegays firſt come all our neighbours;
Then dreſſed
In their beſt,
Came the pipes and the tabors;
Nothing e'er was ſo gay!
At reſt from their labours,
All kept holiday.
Drums were beating, bells ringing,
No one kind of tillage,
Was ſeen in the village,
But all ſorts of paſtime, and dancing, and ſinging;
And then at the church, I remember it yet;
How baſhful you look'd, I ſhall never forget;
And, when aſk'd if your duty as wife you'd fulfil,
Lord, how you did bluſh, when you anſwer'd I will!
Well I remember, &c.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Dear, dear, if there was but any thing we could do!

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Ay, if you would be ſo good to tell us how we could ſerve your honour.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I thank you, my good friends; we are very ſenſible of your kindneſs, but we only mean to repoſe ourſelves in your cottage this evening; where is the Shepherdeſs? where is the beautiful Adelaide? I muſt ſee her again; ſhe is as charming as ever.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Good Sir, our daughter will be here directly. I believe ſhe is getting for you the beſt our poor houſe affords; we call her our daughter; heaven knows whoſe ſhe really is, for we aſk her no queſtions, becauſe we ſee it afflicts her. However, never had child for a father and mother more kindneſs than ſhe has for us; it ſeems as if ſome good angel was ſent among us to comfort us in our old age.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! good man, here ſhe comes.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: Marquis, Marchioneſs, Blaiſe, Renette, and Adelaide, who comes on with Milk in one Hand, and a Baſket of Fruit in the other.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
You are going to ſup in a homely manner, my dear lady, but every thing is clean; our bread is not the whiteſt, but it is new and good; the eggs are freſh,
the milk is warm, and the fruit I have the honour to preſent you, is the beſt the ſeaſon affords.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: With what diligence and attention, with what noble and decent grace, this wonderful ſhepherdeſs renders all the duties of hoſpitality!

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: Marquis, Marchioneſs, Blaiſe, Renette, Adelaide and Guillot, brought on by Dubois, and other of the Marquis's Servants.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Come, come, no reſiſtance; you ſhall be brought before my lord and lady.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What the devil's all this noiſe!

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Guillot!

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: My Nephew Guillot!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What's the matter? ſpeak out, Dubois.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Why, Sir, we have found this thief with my young maſter's clothes on.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: 'Tis true! 'tis true! I know he was robbed and murder'd. Oh! my child! I ſhall never ſee thee again!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but, my dear, now, zounds, hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Save me, uncle Blaiſe, I am as innocent as an unborn babe.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your innocence ſhall be rewarded with a halter.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: What have you done with my child?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Speak boldly, don't be afraid.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Where did you get thoſe clothes?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
I ſwopped mine for them, indeed I did; I ſhould not have taken them, only they were forced on
me; and becauſe I did it to cure Jeannotte of her jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: A very harmleſs thing; go on, my lad; you ſwopped them, you ſay, who did you ſwop them with?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Some thief who has killed my child, and ſo got rid of his clothes to prevent being ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: My dear! zounds, if you interrupt him ſo, how do you expect ever to come at the truth?

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: I don't interrupt him, I only ſay that—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Now, pray, hold your tongue.—Well.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I was going to ſay he did not look at all like a thief; he ſeem'd, to me, more like ſome young gentleman croſſed in love.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Of what age?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh, about my age, and I am twenty to-morrow; my birth-day is once a year—every wine harveſt; and, becauſe of that, Jeannotte and I were to be married.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: His ſize?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: About my ſize; or elſe, you know, our clothes would not have fitted each other; in ſhort, he bought of me every thing I had; my cottage, my flock, my clothes; and ſo, rather than go naked, I put on his; now you know all.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I could have ſworn I was right; 'tis my ſon himſelf, without doubt; and where have you left him?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: In my cottage that was, where he is now ſleeping upon a bed of ſtraw, as happy, I warrant you, as a prince.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: If this is all true, why did you run away from us?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Becauſe you run after me, to be ſure; I did not know but you might be thieves, to tell you the truth; and my uncle can tell you, that I was always frightful from my cradle.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: I have heard his ſtory with ſome attention, and think as you do, that it is your ſon; if it is him, he plays upon the hautboy.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: There are fewer better ſingers in Italy.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I'cod, that's my young man; it would have done your heart good to have heard him this morning, how his ſingers did work it about.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Let us, this inſtant, go and find him.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Now, why the devil do you want to frighten the boy out of his ſleep?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Indeed, in your place, I would not be too precipitate; if you were to diſturb him thus in the middle of the night, perhaps he might fly into the woods.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Good Heaven! you make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Without hazarding this, or without alarming him, let me manage this buſineſs; and, to-morrow, I'll engage to bring him to your arms.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: You have ſeen him then, my dear child?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: I have, madam.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Well, my dear, what the devil, do you think I don't know a little about theſe things? did not I tell you how it was? the truth is, the boy has heard us talk, a thouſand times, in praiſe of Adelaide; from the picture we drew, he fell in love with her; and determined to come here to ſee her; 'tis a fault, but it
is an honeſt fault, the effect of a young head, but movement of a good heart.

lg.l: Our Cares are o'er, he's found! he's found!
Long look'd for is come home at laſt.
Let now appear
Your friendly cheer,
And as the wine we puſh around,
We'll laugh at all our troubles paſt.
And ſo, friend, you and he chang'd clothes?
Yes, ſir, and pleaſe you, that was all;
I meant no harm in it, God knows.
Come, ſir, our table is but ſmall;
Here, Guillot, ſtir thyſelf, my lad;
For madam, put the great arm chair;
Your cheer, I fear, will be but ſad.
'Tis very well, friend Blaiſe, ſit there;
My pretty Adelaide,—nay, don't frown;
Blaize,—Renette—Hey, what neither ſit!
Either, this minute, both ſit down,
Or dam'me! if I eat a bit.
Our cares are over, &c.
Now, if ſweet Adelaide would look gay,
I ſhould have all I could deſire;
Nay, 'tis not fair to turn away
From mirth, which you yourſelf inſpire.
Dear ſir, I'm chearful.
That one ſmile
Went to my heart: there muſt be ways
Found out, her ſorrow to beguile;
I'd have her happy.—Hey, friend Blaiſe,
Ah, ſir, I fain wou'd ſee that hour,
For ſhe's, as 'twere, my child, all one;
But we, I fear, have no ſuch power.
Suppoſe I go and fetch my ſon.
Our cares are o'er, &c.

sp.stage: [The curtain drops at the end of the chorus, as they are ſitting at the table.]

sp.speaker: Adelaide.
sp.p: HEAVENS! for what am I reſerved!—how unlucky was this rencounter with the Marquis and his lady! they have, without intending it, expoſed me to the odious addreſſes of this Abbé, and every danger;—my retreat is diſcovered, and I run a thouſand riſks of being hourly inſulted.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Ah, my lovely girl, I have been looking for you; do you know you have robbed my wife and me of a night's ſleep?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Yes, you—you may remember when we were here before, we uſed every argument in our power to induce you to go with us to Italy; and though afterwards, at your earneſt intreaty, we promiſed never to ſay any more to you on the ſubject, we could hardly refrain from breaking this promiſe.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, don't think of me!—I am put in the world to make every-where unhappineſs.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
Look'e, Adelaide, I would not be thought inquiſitively impertinent; nor do I mean to ſeek any thing but your happineſs. I tell you my wife and I have been debating the matter all night; and, for the firſt time, I believe, this ſeven years, we are both in one mind. In conſequence of our determination, I come to offer you my ſon; we are convinced your birth is as good as ours; and as to fortune, if any
chance has robbed you of that, 'tis lucky my boy has a good ſwinging one to put in his ſcale, which would otherwiſe be overbalanced by your merit. Confide then to us the ſecret of your diſtreſs; I know beforehand, 'tis ſomething that will make you more reſpectable in our eyes, for it is impoſſible that any thing but goodneſs ſhould dwell in ſuch a heart as your's.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Sir, I acknowledge that the notice you have been pleaſed to take of me, is a diſtinction, with which I had no right to flatter myſelf. I confeſs, alſo, that I ought to look upon the offer of your ſon, as a very high compliment; your unparalleled kindneſs will never be eraſed from my memory; but, Sir, there is an abyſs between the world and me, that nothing can overleap.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: My dear child, the more you humiliate yourſelf, the higher you riſe in my eſteem; at leaſt, let me ſhew you the neceſſity of diſcloſing to us your ſituation, that we may know how to ſoften the rigour of your fate. Conſider what a terrible thing it will be to endure the inclemency of the ſeaſons without a friend to ſupport, or aſſiſt you; you'll find no more Blaiſes and Renettes; you'll be an object of envy to the other villagers. Come, come, Adelaide, I have not made ſuch a fine ſpeech a long time, and, pray, don't let it be in vain.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p:
Sir, you ſhall know my ſtory. I am now going to tell it your ſon; he ought not to think of me, and I have no other way of reſtoring him to himſelf and you, than by holding up the unfortunate circumſtances of my life, that he may be the firſt to ſay 'tis impoſſible we ſhould ever be united. Thus you will be acquainted with all my unhappineſs; and in return
for this confidence, I muſt entreat, you, when you leave this place, to take every poſſible precaution to prevent my being an object of odious curioſity; and while you ſtay here, to guard me from importunities, which are as hateful as they are ineffectual.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: That mandrake of an Abbé, I'll lay a million; damn him, I'll cut his ears off. Beautiful young creature, you render yourſelf more and more eſtimable every moment. Be aſſured, you have nothing to do but name your wiſhes, and every thing within my fortune ſhall be your's.

lg.l: My tears—alas! I cannot ſpeak!
Muſt thank this goodneſs, ſure, divine!
For had I words, words are too weak,
Too poor, to vent ſuch thoughts as mine.
The ſun, in its meridian height,
Will gratitude like this inſpire;
Whoſe kindly heat, and piercing light,
We wonder at, and we admire.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I am not very fond of the pathetic, but, ſome how or other, I can't help being touched to the ſoul with this amiable young creature's diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your moſt humble ſervant, Mr. Abbé, [dryly.]

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I have been ſearching for you, Marquis; I have the moſt ridiculous circumſtance in nature to tell you, 'twould be matter for ten ſatirical odes.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: The Count has made me the confident of his amour.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: He has; and my fellow, la Pierre, is now upon the ſearch for the beſt carriage to be found in this miſerable place, to carry off him and his fair one.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: That's excellent!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: And what think you I intend to do?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nay, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: At the moment he gives his hand to the counterfeit Shepherdeſs of the Alps, I will ſtep in with the real one; drive off, and leave the poor, Count in the lurch.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: And you are really ſo egregiouſly conceited to believe this?

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: She has ſeen me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I know ſhe has; and, to cut the matter ſhort, has placed herſelf under my protection; you muſt theretherefore drop all thoughts of her.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Muſt, that's a little ſtrong, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Come, come, Abbé, it won't do; you can't marry her, becauſe you are of the church; and if you meditate any other deſign, it becomes my affair.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Your affair; Which way?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Becauſe, as an honeſt man, this young creature's unfortunate ſituation obliges me to prevent her being inſulted.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: You are rather too old, I ſhould think, to profeſs yourſelf a protector of diſtreſſed damſels, Marquis.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: One can never be too old, puppy, to profeſs one's ſelf a protector of innocence; beſides, I have brought you here; therefore am in ſome degree acceſſary to your outrageous folly; and, a word in your ear—a man may by chance admit a raſcal into his company; but if he finds him out, and does not chaſtiſe him, he is little better than a raſcal himſelf.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Sir, though I don't wear a ſword, I can uſe one.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: To do you juſtice, I know you can, though I ſhould be ſorry to ſee you draw it in ſo unworthy a cauſe. However, if it ſhould be neceſſary, I don't believe I have forgot that kind of ſport myſelf. I have only then one word to ſay to you; you muſt either give me your honour never to ſpeak to Adelaide any more, or you and I are two.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: You and I are two then, my Lord! pen and perſon; I'll not be anſwerable for my actions to you, or any man; I did the girl the honour, I confeſs, to make love to her, and ſhe anſwered me with a great deal of pride, and a great deal of impertinence, which muſt, and ſhall be ſubdued, even though the Marquis of Belemine was ever ſo to profeſs him her knight errant.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Very well, very well, I ſhall watch you; in the mean time, if you think to commit any violence by availing yourſelf of this young creature's defenceleſs ſituation, you are no better than a robber, who would take away her honour becauſe he had a piſtol at her breaſt.

lg.l: Why, is the devil in you!
Or are you ſuch a ninny,
To believe of you ſhe'll ever think, perſwade her all you can?
No, no, whatever believe you,
Your hopes will all deceive you;
For a girl of ſenſe will yield to—not a monkey, but a man.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Zounds! can that hat and feather,
Or the coxcomb altogether,
A ſquire of ſilk—a mandrake—a mere flaſh in the pan;
His pretty ſelf admiring—
Be ought but hate-inſpiring,
When a woman always yields to—not a monkey, but a man.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Then give this folly over;
Nor ſeek to blend the lover
With the ruffian; for I plainly can diſcover that's your plan;
Or ſpight of all your vapouring,
I'll ſo finely ſpoil your capering,
You ſhall own this arm belongs to—not a monkey, but a man.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Dam'me, I'm piqued at this.—Oh, here comes La Pierre.—Well, what news?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! they'll be drawn to matrimony in much the ſame ſtile as they draw criminals to execution; but however, that's not very widely different from the lady's ſituation.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: What, you have got a carriage, then?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and ſuch a one!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Well, but the plan is changed:—I am going in this carriage inſtead of the Count.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: You, ſir!—oh! oh! I ſmoke it. I ſaw you together.—Why, ſir, the bargain has not been long making—ſo modeſt too!—well, who will ever truſt to countenances after this?

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Hold, Monſieur La Pierre; not quite ſo faſt, if you pleaſe: the bargain is not ſo firmly made, but there will be a neceſſity for a little agreeable violence—you underſtand me.—I ſuppoſe it's poſſible to procure three or four ſturdy fellows?

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: Whew!—are we thereabouts? why, this affair will make a noiſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I would have it. In ſhort, this muſt all be done within half an hour; meet me at the cottage, and if you ſee the Count, tell him you can't ſucceed for him.

sp.speaker: La P.
sp.p: I am gone, ſir; I ſuppoſe I may ſay that your honour's purſe is pretty full.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, as to that—and for thee, if I am happy, I'll give thee a ſnug birth in a convent of Benedictines for thy pains.

Thus, before there doubtable Marquis will have time to look about him, will I be far enough with my lovely prey; our little novel will exactly make out the ballad I wrote once upon my ſtealing a nun out of a convent.

lg.l: The coy Paſtora Damon woo'd,
Damon the witty and the gay;
Damon, who never fair purſued,
But ſhe became an eaſy prey.
Yet with this nymph his ev'ry power
In vain he tries, no language moves;
Thus do we ſee the tender flower
Shrink from the ſun whoſe warmth it loves.
Piqued at the little angry puſs,
Cried he, ſhe ſets me all on fire!
Then plagues himſelf, and makes this fuſs,
Only to raiſe her value higher.
For that ſhe loves me every hour,
Each moment, ſome new inſtance proves:
Thus do we ſee the tender flower
Shrink from the ſun whoſe warmth it loves.
How to reſolve then, what reſource?
By fair means ſhe will ne'er come to;
What of a little gentle force,
Suppoſe I try what that will do?
I know ſhe'll tears in torrents pour;
I know her cries will pierce the groves:
Thus do we ſee the tender flower
Shrink from the ſun whoſe warmth it loves.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Marquis, Guillot, Jeannotte, (who come on diſputing.)

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, I tell you, Jeannotte, if you had not been ſo jealous, it would never have happened.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Why, for the matter of that, Guillot, if I had been ever ſo jealous, I don't ſee why—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nay, nay, damn it! don't fall out the moment you have made it up. You have promiſed never to be jealous any more; and you, never to give any cauſe; upon theſe conditions, I ſhall throw ſomething into your purſe; in the mean time, you both remember how I told you to manage the Count.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, never fear, I have got my ſtory.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And ſo have I mine.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Well, here he comes; leave us together for a minute, and come to him when you find him alone; firſt Guillot, and then Jeannotte

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We'll take care.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: So, Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So, Marquis; I have ten thouſand obligations to you: ſhe is ready to go off with me.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: To go off with you! how the devil could you bring her to this?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I don't know; my old way, I inſinuated and inſinuated.—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: 'Till ſhe could refuſe you nothing, eh! why this will make a devil of a clatter at Turin: you'll be envied by the whole world.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I ſhall, indeed.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: And ſo the Counteſs is quite forgotten!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Now, Marquis, that's unfriendly of you; I had juſt got over the firſt ſhock, and you have revived it again in my mind.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Now, damn it, Count, this is ſo abſurd between two ſuch friends as you and I: don't I know what a life you uſed to lead with her?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Horrible, indeed! but to do her juſtice, poor woman, ſhe had a great many virtues.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What virtues! was not ſhe petulant, capricious, ill-tempered?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: As the devil! but then ſhe was divinely handſome.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Handſome! what, with that meagre figure, and her painting herſelf red and white!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I have told her a thouſand times how deteſtable it was: but then her features—

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Were at a mile's diſtance from each other.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To be ſure, they were a little irregular; but, however, in perfection itſelf you may find ſome flaw; we ſee ſpots in the ſun.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Come, come, her perfections, compared to her imperfections, were a drop in the ocean, a grain of pepper upon a turtle; In ſhort, ſhe was a mixture of miſchief and malice; incapable of pleaſing herſelf, and envying all thoſe who could; her delight was to tyrannize over her huſband, and to play the coquette with every body elſe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dam'me, if I did not tell her the very words once myſelf when we quarrelled.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: How different is the preſent object of your wiſhes, gentle, mild, engaging!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh, to rapture!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: So far from thinking herſelf above you, ſhe will look up to you as the author of her good fortune.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Very true, my dear friend, I'll go this minute and beg of her; but, zounds! we can't get a carriage to take us from hence.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I, who am your friend upon all other occaſions, have thought upon that too; there is one Guillot, I fancy, can do your buſineſs; he is nephew to the honeſt people where we are; yonder is the very man; well, I'll leave you together; I am going to ſee if my wife has left her toilet; I ſaw the ſun riſe this morning, and the ceremony put me exactly in mind of a lady's iſſuing from her dreſſing-room.

lg.l: In the month of May,
The morning grey,
Firſt, peeps a doubtful light:
Three ſtrikes the clock,
The village cock
Next crows with all his might
Each waking bird,
Chirping is heard;
Tinges of red the ſky adorn;
Bird, man, and beaſt,
Regard the eaſt,
And, pleas'd, ſalute the riſing morn.
The ſhepherd now his flock unfolds;
Night, like a thief, ſteals ſlow away;
His dingy hue,
Ugly to view,
Is chang'd to a delightful blue;
All nature's gay;
And now the villager beholds
His mowers mow, his ploughers plough,
Sheep bleat, birds ſing, and oxen low:
Each rural ſound ſalutes his ears;
He whiſtles to make one:
And now,
Uſher'd by all this fine parade,
In ev'ry ſplendid pomp array'd,
Appears
The radiant ſun.
So, after abundance of toilet affairs,
And Betty has nine times run up and down ſtairs,
For lappets and ribbands, and one thing and t'other,
And the houſe, top and bottom's alarm'd with the pother,
And a hundred things more are done equally riſible,
The lady, at laſt, condeſcends to be viſible.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: My uncle Blaiſe has lent me ſome clothes, ſo I look a little more like myſelf, and if they catch me being a gentleman again—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Servant, friend.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Your's, ſir, and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: If your name's Guillot, I am informed you can furniſh me with a carriage to take me to Medina.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I believe I could do ſuch a thing. How many perſons is it to carry.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Me and another.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, ſir, but you are the gentleman that's come with the gentlefolks at uncle's, an't you?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am, my friend.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh, I have been ſpoke to about it before.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, may I hope by my charming ſhepherdeſs?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you know who I mean well enough.—I'cod, what a work you have made with her!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe loves me, then?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Loves you! if the King loved me half ſo well, I need not be a poor peaſant here in a village.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And ſo you can get us a carriage? well, I ſhall reward you for it; and pray what ſort of a one is it?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, they ben't the beſt in the world, our way; it will break down five or ſix times before we reach Medina.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Break down!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: O yes, that we always lay our account to; but then we take care and carry a parcel of cords with us, to ſet things right again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Oh, I had rather we could have gone all the way without breaking down.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: If the thing could be, ſo would I too, ſir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, and what ſort of cattle have you?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, as to that, ſir, pretty well, I don't think they'll founder above three times.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Founder!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; we ſhall have three times, I reckon, to ſtop in the ſnow; about five hours at a ſpill.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: In the ſnow!

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; but then your love will keep you warm.

sp.speaker: Count.
