sp.p: To be ſure I would undergo a little in conſideration of that.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And then I hope you are pretty well as to courage, ſir?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Why, ſir; they ſay there's a woundy ſight of robbers that way.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Robbers! hang it, that's unlucky.—Well, but I hope they are none of thoſe damn'd banditti raſcals who murder people?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Always.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: An't you afraid, then, for yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: O Sir, they never touch the guide.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, I muſt conſult the Marquis about it. At all events get ready.—Where ſhall I find you?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh, at uncle's.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You know the way?

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Yes, yes; every inch of it.—Let me ſee.

lg.l: Off we go from Break-neck-ſteep,
Softly, ſoftly, jades, ſo! ſo!
'Till we ſee the mountains peep,
Cover'd with huge heaps of ſnow.
But ſmall matters travellers never muſt mind;
We laugh at each ſtumble, and ſing at each trip;
For you, ſir, d'ye ſee,
You've to cheer up your ſpirits, a kind coming fair,
Who, the more we're in danger, the more will be kind.
And then, as for me,
I've a drop in my pocket to keep out the air,
And I'm always reviv'd at the ſmack of the whip.
By-and-by to Cripple-hill,
Tired and jaded we arrive;
Where, for ſome hours, we ſtand ſtill,
The worn-out cattle ſcarce alive.
But ſmall matters, &c.
'See the carriage one ſide hang,
'And now upon its end, and now,
'Apart the breaking traces bang,
'And ſouſe we tumble in a ſlough.
'But ſmall matters, &c.'
Next, to Cut-throat dale we reach;
Where, from behind ſome lonely buſh,
With blunderbuſs, and piſtols each,
A dozen lurking villains ruſh.
But ſmall matters, &c.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I muſt throw none of theſe objections in her way:—here ſhe is. Well, my love, you are come in good time: we ſhall have a carriage directly, and then upon the wings of love.—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Ay, all that's very well, if I could believe you'd love me for ever.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How can you think otherwiſe? who would not have done as much as I have, for the tender, gentle, beautiful Shepherdeſs of the Alps? your diſtreſs beſpoke my pity; pity ſoftened into love, and love commanded me to throw myſelf and my fortune at your feet.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Yes, but ours has been but a ſhort acquaintance; and how do I know but you wants to inveigle me away for ſome wicked purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My dear, I would not harbour ſuch a thought for the world: my intention is to take you directly to Turin, there to beſpeak you clothes, jewels, every thing proper for your intended ſituation; and when my twelvemonth and a day expires, to marry you.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Twelvemonth and a day!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, my dear; you know it would not be decent before.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: I can tell you, Sir, I won't wait ſo long as that:—to love you ſo dearly as I do, indeed, and not be married 'till then!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But, my life, what can I do?

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Why? marry me before you go.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Conſider, love:—beſides there's no ſuch thing as getting a prieſt.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: O Lord! our curate will do the job, and thank you into the bargain, if you'll give him a good fee; and then, as I am to be a lady, you know, I can't ſee why you may not bring me acquainted with the gentlefolks, and then we may all go away together.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: That's true; but if they find I have made ſuch a ſudden reſolution—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: They may laugh at you, perhaps you think; Oh, ſir, if you are aſhamed of your choice, indeed!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, my life, it is not that.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: I can tell you, ſir, I would not turn my back for virtue and honeſty to any one; and then as to beauty—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Venus was never half ſo handſome.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: I don't know ſhe, but I am ſure I am very well to paſs.

sp.speaker: Count,
sp.p: Zounds! I ſhall loſe her. My love, you are every thing to me, and your will ſhall be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Ay, that's ſaying ſomething; but I think you had better make me acquainted with the gentlefolks firſt, and then you may get one of your friends to ſtand father.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A good thought.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: And another thing;—you don't think of marrying me in that diſmal ſuit of clothes, do you?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My dear, I have no other with me.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Oh, I dare ſay the gentleman will lend you ſome.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, but.—

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Ah, there! You are at your buts again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll make no objections; every thing ſhall be as you deſire it: I'll go and find the Marquis directly.—Adieu.

sp.speaker: Jean.
sp.p: Oh dear! how I ſhall laugh to ſee him in his finery.

lg.l: Ah men what ſilly things you are,
To woman thus to humble;
Who, fowler like, but ſpreads her ſnare,
Or at her timid game,
Takes aim,
Pop, pop, and down you tumble.
She marks you down, fly where you will,
O'er clover, graſs, or ſtubble;
Can wing you, feather you, or kill,
Juſt as ſhe takes the trouble.
Ah men, &c.
Then fly not from us, 'tis in vain,
We know the art of ſetting,
As well as ſhooting, and can train
The ſhyeſt man our not in.
Ah men, &c.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: The Tomb ſeen in another point of View.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Three hours have I waited here in anxious expectation, contemplating every one of thoſe objects that have ſo often been ſilent witneſſes of her grief:—all nature ſeems to reſpect it—and where-e'er ſhe comes, like gloomy miſts at the approach of day, all other objects ſhrink back, and behold her approach with ſilent admiration—what can it be?

lg.l: Bright gems that twinkle from afar,
Planets, and every leſſer ſtar,
Who darting each a downward ray,
Conſole us for the loſs of day.
Begone, even Venus who ſo bright,
Reflects her viſions pure and white;
Inſtant begone, and quit the ſkies,
For lo! the moon begins to riſe.
Ye pretty warblers of the grove,
Who chant ſuch artleſs tales of love;
The throſtle, gurgling in his throat;
The linnet, with his ſilver note.
The ſoaring lark, the whiſtling thruſh,
The merry blackbird, goldfinch, huſh,
Fly, vaniſh, diſappear, take wing,
The nightingale begins to ſing.

sp.p: But ſhe is here, and all at once the blood forſakes my very heart; how I tremble to approach her!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: I have made you wait; but I'll haſten to recompenſe your patience; you know upon what conditions you are to hear my ſtory; let us ſpeak to one another then without diſguiſe. I'll begin, and let my confidence encourage your's; liſten—my unhappineſs will be a leſſon for you—Shepherd, behold this tomb.

lg.l: Here ſleeps in peace, beneath this ruſtic vaſe,
The tendereſt lover a huſband could prove;
Of all his diſtreſs, alas, I am the cauſe;
So much I ador'd him, heaven envied my love.
The ſighs I reſpire ev'ry morn I ariſe,
The miſery I cheriſh, the grief, and the pain;
The thouſand of tears that fall from my eyes,
Are all the ſad comforts, for me, that remain.
When, his colours diſplay'd, honour call'd him to arms;
By tender perſwaſions I kept him away;
His glory forgetting for thoſe fatal charms;
And, to puniſh me, he is depriv'd of the day.
Since when to his memory I've rais'd this ſad tomb,
Where to join him, alas! I ſhall ſhortly deſcend;
Where ſorrow, nor pain, nor affliction can come,
And where both my love, and my crime ſhall have end.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Now tell me of what parents you are born, and what reduced you to the ſtate of ſhepherd?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Ceaſe to queſtion me, 'twould afflict you to know an ill you cannot cure. You are unhappy, but I am more ſo; and ſuch is the nature of my diſtreſs, that an eternal ſilence muſt lock it up in my heart.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas! how can I without knowing who you are, and what are your troubles, any longer place a confidence in you? the myſtery you make raiſes a cloud between us.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Don't be offended at my ſilence! 'tis terrible to be condemned to it. The aſſiduous companion of all your ſteps, I'll ſweeten your labour; I'll partake your cares, and you ſhall never repent of having repoſed your miſeries in a heart, alas! but too ſenſible.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: No, it cannot be; I exact from you the moſt ſincere confeſſion, and I think I merit it; I have ſpoken to you without myſtery, and you ought to imitate me.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Alas! let me finiſh my deplorable life, without leaving you to reproach yourſelf with having ſhortened it.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Sill more and more myſterious.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: What would you have me ſay then?—I am—

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Bellemine! the ſon of thoſe travellers you ſo penetrated with reſpect and admiration.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: And you have left your unhappy family in tears?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Their report of your virtues and your charms, inſpired me with the fatal deſign to come and ſee you thus diſguiſed; you therefore know the cauſe of my error.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: O fly and conſole—

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Spare me unuſeful counſels and reproaches; my reſolution is as fixed, as unalterable as your's; I ſee all the repugnance you have to make me unhappy; I ſee your heart is with him who repoſes in that tomb; I ſee that nothing can detach you from it; your duty is never to love me, and my fate for ever to adore you.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: [Looking after him] Poor Bellemine!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Here ſhe is. Come, ma'am, you ſeem a lady fond of adventures, and therefore I hope you'll not make much reſiſtance; come let me gently force you to be happy.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: [Taking hold of her.] My dear, I can't t •… k, I ſhall have time enough to obtain my pardon: here my honeſt fellows, aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Oh, [ſhrieks] Heaven! what would you do?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: How's this? Adelaide in diſtreſs!—hold off, you ruffians! [They turn upon him, Adelaide runs off] Nay, I regard not your numbers. What do I ſee, the Abbé dela Mouche!

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Young Bellemine!

stage.hi: Abbé, Young Bellemine, Marquis, Marchioneſs Adelaide, Blaiſe, Renette.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: [Speaking as he comes on] Where are they? where are they? never fear my boy, the dog has courage enough.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: My father! gods!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: [Shewing Young Bellemine to his mother] Madam, I have fulfilled my promiſe.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: So, Mr. Abbé you are there! did not I tell you, you had better be quiet? you little thought what a terrier I had to ſet after your heels.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: I little expected, indeed, the pleaſure of ſeeing Mr. Bellemine.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Nor that you ſhould be chaſtized, I ſuppoſe, for the outrage you have meditated againſt decency, and the laws.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Sir, there's no talking here; you'll find me at Turin.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I will find you at Turin, Sir; in the mean time begone! and thank this company that I part with you upon ſuch eaſy terms.

sp.speaker: Abbé.
sp.p: Here, la Pierre; at Turin, Mr. Bellemine, I ſhall expect the pleaſure of ſeeing you, Sir; in the mean time, I am this company's moſt obedient ſlave.

lg.l: Thus do we find the tender flower
Shrink from the ſun whoſe warmth it loves.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: So, you young dog, I have had a pretty race after you, I think.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, nor make me more miſerable than I am.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Oh, my dear child, why would you be ſo cruel to leave me in ſuch deſpair?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I feel, madam, how much theſe reproaches are my due; but by the ills I endure, love is revenged of nature, and your ſon is loſt.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: How! my child?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: I have done every thing, quitted every thing for her; anſwer me, could I love any thing more beautiful? but I adore in vain; a young and faithful widow, ſhe weeps a huſband buried in that tomb.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: 'Tis for that then, ſo young and handſome, ſhe has quitted the world.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: The name of your huſband, my dear child?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Doreſtan.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: And your's?

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Seville.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Why, I know both the names as well, as my own. Did not I ſay my boy knew what he was about? why, you dog, ſhe is deſcended from one of the beſt families in France.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Indeed, child, her heart was worthy of you; but the love you have conceived for her, is a flame that muſt be extinguiſhed.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: If I muſt quit Adelaide, I ſhall ſoon after quit the light; I feel too well, that the ſame inſtant will decide my life and my love.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: You ſee, child, his extreme unhappineſs.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Ah! how miſerable I am!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Come, come, why ſhould we ſtay here to afflict her? I did not believe it a matter ſo ſerious as this: we won't aſk you, Adelaide, to accompany us.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: I wiſh to heaven ſhe would.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas! madam, how can I?

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Adieu, all that I love. [Tenderly.]

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Adieu, Bellemine. [Heſitating.]

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Oh, what an effort! no, I feel I ſhall ſink under it; let me then upon this tomb.
sp.stage: [He is going to throw himſelf upon the tomb, and the Marquis catches him in his arms.]

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Alas! Adelaide, your heart is without pity, and for a family too who have ſo much friendſhip for you.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Dear madam, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: I would have you go with us: I aſk not for a return of my child's love, your pity will ſuffice, and that I implore; without that, you'll cauſe his death; and alas, mine ſoon afterwards!

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Dear madam.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Save my child! make this effort; a mother upon her knees aſks his life.

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear child, you make madam too unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: Pray, pray, conſent.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Adelaide, I muſt put in a word now: how can you deny us? beſides your adventure will be known every where; nay, have you not already been expoſed to violence? though, thanks to my boy, you were reſcued from it: for his ſake then, for your own,—

sp.speaker: Blaiſe.
sp.p: For all our ſakes.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.stage: [She looks ſeparately at them all, as they ſupplicate her, and at laſt goes up to the tomb.]
sp.p: Oh Doreſtan, thy heart was noble and generous; and if thou canſt read in the bottom of my mind, thou wilt not complain of ſo holy a duty.—Riſe, Bellemine!

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: What voice was that! [ſtarting up.]

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What voice! why the voice of thy Adelaide, who conſents to go with us to Turin; oh! you young dog, you have got the uſe of your limbs now, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: Oh, my Adelaide!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What the devil have we here?

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: Marquis, Marchioneſs, Y. B. Adelaide, Blaiſe, Renette, Count, Jeannotte. [The Count dreſſed out.]

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Give me joy! my friends, give me joy!

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: Ah, the Count!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, not the whining, crying Count; but the laughing, happy Count; zounds! I can't help thinking what an aſs I have been; to be ſure, 'tis a ſudden change; but who'll blame me when they know what a temptation was thrown in my way; the lovely, ſolitary ſhepherdeſs of the Alps!

sp.speaker: Y. B.
sp.p: How's this!

div.head: SCENE the laſt.
div.stage: To them, Guillot dreſſed for his Journey.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: I crave pardon; oh! Sir, you are there; well, every thing is ready, the cattle are too— [ſeeing Jeannotte toying with the Count.] Heyday! Jeannotte, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Jeannotte! what does the fellow mean by Jeannotte? Sir, this is the lovely Adelaide; the Shepherdeſs of the Alps.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: Oh lord! I know a little better than that too; 'tis our Jeannotte, I tell you; and, to ſay the truth, I don't underſtand her toying about along of you, when ſhe is to be married this morning to me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What is all this, Marquis?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Count, I aſſure you; yonder's Adelaide with my ſon.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And have I then ſwerved from my duty; dreſſed myſelf up like a mountebank? this was your contrivance then, Marquis.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: It was indeed, Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, why?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: I'll tell you why: from an inveterate averſion I have to every ſort of hypocriſy; come, come, I'll ſettle all your future ſituations: you and Jeannotte ſhall enjoy your farm; which my ſon ſhall reſtore you again; Blaiſe and Renette ſhall go with us; and, as they have lived like Baucis and Philemon, ſo ſhall they die; for I'll change their cottage into a palace—As for you, Count—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I am a wretch, a puppy; I feel it, and will never ſhew my face again; I'll get into my weeds, and never more be comforted.

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p:
An excellent reſolution! and there never was ſo fine an opportunity; and dam'me, if I was you, I'd ſtay here in theſe wild mountains; let my hair and my claws grew, and vegetage, like Nebuchadnezzar;
and now, my amiable daughter, we'll reſtore you to the world.

sp.speaker: Ade.
sp.p: Alas, ſir! how ſhall I bear its reproaches?

sp.speaker: Marq.
sp.p: What reproaches! let it have been witneſs to our united ſolicitations, let it have ſeen the noble conflict in your mind, and then, could the ſevereſt cenſurer have denied, that the Shepherdeſs of the Alps was amiable, even in her infidelity?

lg.l: Each kind auſpicious power,
If goodneſs is your care,
Exhauſtleſs bleſſings ſhower
Upon this tender pair.
Ah me! what joy! no never
Will I again repine;
My Adelaide is, for ever,
Ye powers! for ever mine;
Ne'er will I let her languiſh,
But every care employ
To turn, each tear of anguiſh
Into a ſmile of joy.
Thus trying to deſerve her all I may,
I'll give the talking world right cauſe to ſay—
Each kind auſpicious power,
If goodneſs is your care,
Exhauſtleſs bleſſings ſhower
Upon this tender pair.
Adieu, ye woods, ye fountains,
Adieu, my pretty ſheep,
Who oft' have left the mountains,
And gaz'd to ſee me weep.
And ah! may'ſt thou acquit me,
Belov'd and honour'd ſhade,
And own, as did befit me,
I every duty paid.
Not but a tear, thy tribute, oft' I'll pay,
That all the world may ſtill have cauſe to ſay—
Each kind auſpicious power,
If goodneſs is your care,
Exhauſtleſs bleſſings ſhower
Upon this tender pair.
Now critics, your election
We wait with anxious care;
Oh! give your kind protection
To this, elſe, wretched pair!
To comfort her's your duty;
For ſhould you give her pain,
'Twill be the firſt time beauty
Has pleaded here in vain.
No, rather ſend us, ſmiling, all away;
And, joining chorus, clap your hands and ſay—
Each kind auſpicious power,
If goodneſs is your care,
Exhauſtleſs bleſſings ſhower
Upon this tender pair.
